reviewText:
There is no conditional recommendation feature on Steam, because of this I cannot recommend, however the program can be useful to would be flight simmers.

The idea behind Dovetail Games Flight School is to give newcomers to the genre a taste of what flight sims are all about at a reasonable price. For me it misses the mark, though the price is reasonable.

The program offers the ability to gain two pilots licences by completing various tasks that form part of the basic mechanics of general aviation flying. It doesn’t give much by way of an understanding though, it is good at telling you what to do, but not as good at telling you why.

The program also offers a number of missions of varying difficulty. These are fun, but are at the same time quite frustrating.

Finally the program also offers the ability to freely fly anywhere on the planet using the two (soon to be three) supplied aircraft.

I have used the program for just over 9 hours at the time of writing and my overall experience can only be described as one of frustration. I have over a thousand hours under my belt with FSX:SE and FSX before it, I found the amount of information made available to the pilot prior to any task or mission lacking.

Simple things, like what the heading is of the runway you are being sent to for a mission, some of the strips are very tight. If you aren’t able to set up a good approach it just makes things more difficult and frustrating.

In the lessons, you don’t get to find out exactly what you are going to do until you are trying to trim the aircraft, monitor the speed/throttle and check your heading while the instructor is also filling you in on the facts as to why you are in the air in the first place. This usually results in a failure of that particular mission/task, lots of swearing at the monitor and another attempt. At least you have a better understanding of what the objective is second or third time round.

Now I haven’t been to flight school IRL, I do think though that I would receive a full briefing of what todays lesson was going to be before I got anywhere near the aircraft.

If you can ride the waves of frustration and persevere with the lessons/missions, there is a sense of achievement upon completion. If you do this, there is a good chance that you will enjoy a step up to FSX, P3D, X-Plane or DTG’s upcoming Flight Simulator, so maybe the program is really just one big test.

Despite community hub complaints, I find the graphics far better than many of the available flight sims that have global coverage out of the box. Just make sure your rig comfortably meets the spec requirements and you will have access to a program that performs and looks as good as a £100+ spend on other sims for the sweet price of £11, though there is room for some improvement (clouds, sky, mid-day ambient lighting).

To summarise. It’s a cheap way to find out if you are willing to shell out substantially more on a good flight simulator. If you can put up with the programs foibles it is a good indication that this genre is for you.

<TL;DR>
If you are just testing the water for flight simming this will put you off more than encourage you to progress. If you think it is something you really want to get into, a little perseverance will help in making your mind up.
</TL;DR>

This is a good simulator at a great price!  It is meant to be for people who are somewhat new to flying.  So, I am confused why people are comparing it to full fledged flight simulations like FSX.  I am also hearing that Dovetail is planning on releasing a full fledged simulator later on this year.

Anyhow, this is what this review will focus on what's there right now.

PROS:
- Easy to get started
- Tutorial has some minor issues (too picky when you fly off course)
- Graphics are nice and smooth for me (Windows 10, GTX 680)
- Realism is settled somewhere between MS Flight and FSX, but that's a pro for someone who just wants to take a quick spin
- Convers entire world with good global airport availability

CONS:
- Tutorial has some minor issues (too picky when you fly off course)
- You should have a controller (I couldn't fly it with using a mouse, but it does work using a keyboard)
- Realism could be better
- Graphics are detailed in some areas, but can be a hit or miss in others
- Only two planes (hopefully, this will be fixed in a patch soon)


My takeaway is that this simulator is aimed at beginners or people who just want to take a quick spin.  It delivers that easily!  At the same time, it brings just a little bit more depth to catch the interest of people who have some flight experience by adding global scenery with a semi-realistic flight model.

Last, but not least, it is available for the low price of $15.  So, you can't really go wrong and it seems to be a good value for what it delivers.

reviewText:
DTG never intended for this game to be a replacement for Microsoft Flight Simulator X: Steam Edition.  Rather, this game is meant to do two things:
1) Give them a chance to test FSX technology with DirectX 11  and 64-bit processing in preparation for their Dovetail Flight Simulator game.
2) Make flight simming accessible to those who have always wanted to learn but don't want to purchase full-blown sims.

The lessons are not complete and motivated students would do well to take notes and look things up online to fill in the gaps.  FSc does not have an extensive in-game library of knowledge like FSX.  However, they take the students straight in the airplanes without any ground school lessons in an attempt to get them to try things hands-on.

The missions, at least for me, are all easy to slightly difficult.  Only one mission is a toughie and unfortunately the lessons won't prepare students well for it.

The free flight mode is much easier to access than FSX:SE, but it has unfortunately been stripped down.  You can fly VFR only and you need to use the useful in-game GPS (which has no in-game instruction explaining its use) to look up things like ILS frequencies and headings for upcoming waypoints.

The colors in the game are pretty bad compared to FSX:SE, which is a letdown when you consider that FSX was released 10 years ago and still looks better right out of the box.  Unfortunately I do not feel that the Orbx terrain add much to the visuals.  The two planes are nice to fly, and have somewhat functional cockpits.  The frame rate on my computer is good.

For US $15, Dovetail Flight School will absolutely not replace your current flight simulator if you already have one.  However, it is a challenge for newbies and a good refresher for veterans.  This game gives a glimpse of what DTG hopes they can produce by the end of this year.  Those who are ready to graduate from Dovetail Flight School and cannot wait for that new sim will feel right at home with FSX:SE.

reviewText:
Pros:
- Uses hyperthreading effectively
- UI is snappy and responsive
- Full world to explore
- VFR Flight planner is a huge improvement from the previous flight simulators
- Rendering performance is fast and smooth -- low variance in frame times (even better if you optionally lock your maximum frame rate). Frame rates consistently above 45 FPS.
- Lessons feature high quality dialogue. Brought back nolstagia of my own flight school experiences when I was younger.
- Night lighting is exquisite.
-  ORBX's FTX Global is included ($80 value)
- Lighting on the plane and it's cockpit is beautiful. Very fine job.
- Flight model improvements. Stalling after prematurely leaving ground effect before adequate speed killed me -- twice. Adverse yaw correctly modeled. Stalls and spins improved.

Cons:
- Lighting contrast during the day is horrible. Some of the trees look like splotchy, very dark green textures.
- Clouds are not shaded correctly. It seems the shaded part of the cloud never takes into consideration of the Sun's azimuth.
- Antialiasing needs work. Looks to use some kind of SMAA. We need real MSAA.
- Cannot change the time of day after a flight has started. In fact many of the menu bar options in FSX have been removed. For better and worse.
- No SDK for user submitted content.
- No LOD_Radius and frame lock options in the options. Have to manually edit the fsc.cfg.

Overall, I recommend this experience for newcomers into the hobby. The lessons are high quality and reminded me of my own flight school experiences. It's cheap and effective. Older members of the hobby will probably find not much value in this if they disregard the lesson portion of this product. Other simulators are more comprehensive in the free flight experience. For the flight school experience, this one takes the cake.

PROS:

64-bit GOODNESS
Letting you use all that RAM is a must not just in your typical AAA games but simulators that use huge sceneries can definitely benefit from this.

SLIGHTLY BETTER GRAPHICS
This is actually a 50/50 but let me focus on the positive. The planes are highly detailed. I really like the texture. I can only imagine what the DA42 is gonna look like.

The lessons covered enough ground for new flight simmers to begin their aviation journey although some parts of the lessons are not well instructed or a bit confusing(watch Squirrel's videos).

FLIGHT MODEL AND PHYSICS
It feels good. After all, this is modeled from FSX.

PILOT PROFILE AND UNLOCKING MISSIONS
You put in the flight hours, you get to unlock the missions. Gives the player an initiative to learn and fly some more.

REASONABLE PRICE
Although I'd rather fly lessons in a full flight simulator, one can agree that you're certainly getting a good deal with DTG Flight School at its price.

CONS:

PRE-ORDER PROMISE
When I first saw their announcement on Steam, it got me excited. A possible predecessor to FSX is coming and you'll get a DA42 if you pre-order. Cool. Let me pre-order that. Announcement said April 24 or 25(can't remember) was the release date. Come that date, no game. WTH?! Got moved by a month. The action button shows up in upper left corner and if you hover over it, it shows the action at the bottom right part of the screen. I also noticed that changing key mapping is somewhat hidden". BUGS

UGLY PANELS
I can't believe what I saw when I saw it. The 2D panels from FSX even looked more detailed and better. The 2D radio comms from both the default aircrafts lookedl ike they were in alpha. Seriously
recommended: this game and the upcoming Flight Simulator shows promise. But I don't recommend this for flight sim enthusiasts. Newcomers are getting a reasonable product for a reasonable price. I would have to refund this for now and wait for their FS later this year.\n"

I'm a fan of flight sims and played lots of them, and from my experience of talking to people not really into it I can understand why it seems pointless and boring, especially with only 2 (3?) planes, the graphics maybe 10% better than 10 years ago, and overall it doesn't even feel like a game.

BUT, comparing to other sims, I can say several things in defence of this game:

1. If you want a beautiful sim, this is your choice. From the graphics and performance pov, it's the best sim ever. Well, there haven't been a lot lately, but this brings me to point 2...
2. It's very hard to make a good flight sim, especially one including the whole world. When Google Earth will look like NYC everywhere in the world without taking 300TB on your PC we'll have something to talk about.
3. The controls and physics feel real. With the weather conditions and all... It's really a sim (unlike X-plane who claim to have the realest physics but IMHO they don't). So if you wan't to feel what it's like to control a plane, this is your choice.
4. I like the lessons. Easy step by step basics to people who never played a sim.

NOW, I do have a couple of remarks for improvement:

1. Considering it's 2016, it's kinda disappointing how obvious it is that it's based on MFS. This really is an improved MFS like some said, in which many of us spent thousands of hours (me personally 2002, 2004, X, and it feels like almost the same game many many years later). The direction of adapting dotays technologies is great, but looks like too much is re-used.
2. I hope to see more planes in this game, not the next. I bought this game. I'm glad to be part of this interesting POC but I'd like to get a little more than 2 small Pipers without even auto-pilot.

Bottom line, it's a nice game to try if you're a simmer, or maybe wait for the real thing (although it's only 15$).
If you're new to flight sims, this is the BEST to start with.

reviewText:
Flight School is a wonderful game that falls woefully short.  This game, which uses the FSX engine, fails to capitalize on that strength and does very little to help introduce a new user to the world of flight sims, whether it's FSX, Prepar3d, or any future flight simulator DTG may release.

This game's shortcomings fall on the lack of airplanes available, and the lack of airplanes means a lack of skills a pilot will develop.  Starting users off with the Piper Super Cub and Piper Cherokee are an excellent way to get a new user flying and to teach them the basics, but there is only so much you can do with these planes.  Once you master them, that's it.  There are no additional planes (or lessons) that will teach you how to fly with IFR, how to navigate with NDB's, how to operate an autopilot, how to land using ILS, or even how to fly an airplane that has a glass cockpit.  There is a Garmin GPS unit included with each airplane, but this game doesn't teach you how to use that either.

The other problem is with the flight planner in free-flight mode, which doesn't allow you to do much planning with it.  Sure, you can plot a route from one direction to the next, but again, this game doesn't give you the tools to properly plan a flight.  For example, if you want to navigate by using VOR, a compass isn't included to help you determine what radial you should be using to set the OBS on your VOR indicator.  Knowing how to fly stick-and-rudder is an important skill, but knowing how to get yourself from A to B is equally important.  Without proper flight planning tools at your disposal, the free-flight portion of the game is useless and does nothing to help a pilot hone their skills.

The missions are the only bright spot in the game, as they are short enough to keep you entertained, and they do have challenges that force you to think outside the box.  But, I think it's a mistake to not have the time spent flying these missions count toward the minimum flight time needed to qualify for a license.

This game could've been much greater than it is, but the lack of lessons to help develop a pilot hurts this game more than the graphics quality that others have complained about. Cons

- Too small improvments on graphic except optimize. Basic graphic were close to FSX+Orbx Global. Ground Autogen, Cloud, weather effect... they didn't seem any improvement from FSX's one. Definatly Not a 'modern graphic' and either 'improved from FSX's one'.
- Land data were just reuse of old FSX's one. Seoul didn't have 2 islands, only one and that one islands has wrong shape. Why they just reuse it?

Who recommend to buy
* Want to play a good light aircraft simulation on cheap price

Who didn't recommend to buy

reviewText:
So, let me introduce myself. I'm an hardcore flightsimmer, 22 years old and 16 years of simulation (i started on FS4). I got a 5000h record on IVAO and 2000 on VATSIM. A 30 000+ total on FSX and i'm pretty sure that, every simulator combined (DCS, Condor, Falcon 4, X-Plane), i'm close to 40 or 50 000h of flying. It's been 1 year that i've really slow down simulation, so it was a renewal for me. A way to see where the market was going on and if there was any improvement.

Do the graphics are bad ?

No. Yes, the contrast is horrible (the same i've found in P3D and X-Plane 10, i hate it) and the clouds are uglier than FSX's. But the autogen is way better (waaaaaaay better) and ground textures also (especially at night). Planes are good looking, and more realistic, relatively speaking to what FS's previously offered.

Plus, the first two problems are easily fixed.

How much more realistic ?

Not really that much compared to FSX. Overall feeling is the same, and aircraft.cfg didn't change one inch. But failures are slightly better managed now.

Buggy ?

Not at all on my PC, but there's report saying that yes it's buggy and even laggy. Didn't have any of these two problems.

Is the content up to the price ?

It really depends.

Missions are very short (some even 1 minute), and there's only 9 of them. There are a little bit more lessons. But not that much. Though, lessons are very good, and missions are realistic. Overall the content is good but it lacks of it.

+ There's only 2 (3 for pre-order) planes and you can't add any of your FSX/P3D planes (for now ?).

Well for 15€ i consider it a very good and challenging sim for wannabe hardcore pilots. They'll get a fairly good experience. Now, if the devs repair some of the above problems (for free that is) it could also be good little sim (Aerofly-alike) to keep you close from the flightsim community. Especially if modding is added.

Do you recommend it ?

Until there's a public plan for the future : no. It's expensive for what we have now. Wait a little, come back, see what's there and maybe it will be a very good flight sim school. For now it's an average good-looking flight sim school. But it's promising for Dovetail's future in the flight simulation market (if they don't hold us up with their own addons).

P.S : Dovetail dev, if you are reading this, the hours threshold on LAPL & PPL flight lessons are really annoying. I don't want to free flight three hours just to access the exams. Especially if my other flights didn't count for total flight hours.

For the price, DTG Flight School is good value and a good introduction to the world of flight simulation. Having been a heavy user of FSX, PrePar 3D and X-Plane over the years, I can see how DTG Flight School fits in and it does it well.

Apart from setting up your controller it seems straight forward and easy to get flying. The lessons are not bad and you can then still fly all over the world just like in FSX:SE. The graphics and flight dynamics may not match my maxed out PrePar 3D or FSX:SE (using hundreds of dollars of addons and many hours of tweaking) but they are still pretty good and from my results the framerate on any half decent system should also be good. This game still requires a certain amount of power from your PC and trying to run it on one that is too low spec will cause you pain.

It offers nothing more then FSX:SE does (except the lessons, etc.) but as an introduction to flying for the new person it is worth the money. If you want to learn the basics of flying then get it. If you want the full involved experience of flight simulation then look at one of the others.

Bear in mind that you will not be able to install any non-DTG aircraft or scenery addons in this simulator and just look at it as an in-expensive way to try out the world of flight simulation. If you do that, you should be happy.

I've been flying FSX for years, but I've probably never made a single flight that wouldn't have ended in a terrible crash in the real world. I've never been able to take a sensible, realistic flight. But now, I think I might be taking my first steps towards being a half decent PC pilot.

If you're doing something wrong, you either get hastled repeatedly until you get it right or you don't get a warning at all. If you bank left instead of right (which I did on more than one occasion) nobody warns you. Then, when you reach the end the instructor suddenly realizes you're in the wrong place all together, you have to restart. I've done each of the lessons twice because of this. I feel the lessons should be a little more forgiving and improvised to a degree, but that hasn't stopped me from learning.

One thing I'd love to see, if this ever gets another look in by the developers, is another progression to more advanced trainer aircraft like the T6 Texan or the PC-9. That would be a great help to students like me who want to be able to taker bigger and better aircraft.

This glimpse into what DTG is doing with the flight simulator series is very promising. A magnificent graphic improvement on the last instalment (albeit with a few glitches) makes me feel much more immersed in the experience, especially in the two great aircraft inculded. I can see exactly what this simulator is all about and I think it's a very reasonable price for what you get with it. I can't wait for the comming release at the end of the year.

To the extent this is the first experiment with using the FSX game in a 64 bit format I am very excited. At $16.00 the limitations should be obvious as this was intended to be the first foray in using the engine in 64 bit. And what a joy to have all the graphics cranked up and see 4.1 gb used huge framerates and using only 35% of available memory. I cranked up the LOD radius to 12.000000 and looks even more beautiful. FPS dropped as expected but to a very nice 40 fps and memeory went up to 4.5 gb with available memory noted at 45% so lots of headroom.

LOD of the mesh is very good. Fly in Austria and you'll find out. Not those stupid rounded mountains of FSX.

ORBX has supplied the Global Base and I'm assuming Vector and Open LC as well. Very nice and again a huge improvement over default FSX. Plenty of autogen - trees and buildings give the scenery a robust look. Would have like Speedtrees implemented something P3D did.

Don't know what all the *itching is about. This is the beginning framework for 64 bit and after years running up against out of memory in pathetic 32 bit BRAVO to Dovetail. Hugely excited for the full monty fit as tentatively noted in the fall.

In the meantime I like the school, the missions, and the free flying, UI is easy enough to navigate. Flightplanning is fun. Keep it up Dovetail!

First off, I have said this before and will repeat it again: gamers are the biggest whiners, bar none and of age.

For some reason people believe they have a right to write whatever they feel like it because they sit behind a screen and keyboard. I have actually  met people who have written  nasty things about me in real life and all I can say is that all of them have been insecure people who would never behave or say what they normally write behind a keyboard. Sad state of affairs. Same type of people who seek confrontation over things normal people just let slide and move along because it is not about life or death.

Secondly, how old are you people really who write some of the garbage here? I have spent 15 euros and got what a reasonable person can expect from an entry level flight simulator based on a 2006 engine. You want a fully featured flight simulator buy FSX or Xplane 10. At no  point was this advertised as a successor to FSX. It is a rebuild of FSX in 64-bit environment with updated scenary textures such as buildings and various environmental textures. The successor to FSX is coming later this year, it has been repeatdly layed out in interviews and various articles.

Finally, about the game. I have played sims since Sublogic days on Apple and monochrome days, especially Flight Simulator. I have also flown small Cessna planes although not completed any official license and dont intend to at the moment.

The graphics at full resolution and maxed out do look like the screen shoots. It is not that hard. Full settings, 1920x1080 resolution and you get the same results, seriously people just try it. If you dont have the horsepower then that is how it works, it is PC gaming after all. The FPS are slightly lower with somewhat comparable settings on FSX but it is hard to compare. There is not alot of customization for the graphics, only sliders, but OK, that is how it is.

Flight model is allright, it does its job for being an entry level flight simulator.

2 planes, that is what was advertised and that is what it has, period.

I had higher expectations myself but I enjoyed it for what it is. I wish I could customize things such as weather and a more precise scenary control panel but OK.

I remember FSX the day it came out, it was not running very well but with service pack it most things were taken care of. For those who say MS Flight should be revived...you know why they ditched that? The community said it was not what they wanted. Personally, I thought it was at best mediocre, it was an attempt to test if the community was still alive. MS Flight should stay where it is...in the past.

reviewText:
My feedback in short about DTFSc, after spending a few hours in the various sections, I find it good and pleasant, and happy to see the premises of the future successor of FSX SE.

IMHO, DTFSc can be described as a mix between a game and a simulator. Learn the basics of flying, which is a tough topic, while having fun. Isn’t that good :) After that, ready to enter into a more complex and global simulator, like FSX or so.

Probably we don't learn all the details of piloting, FSX learning center lessons are more detailed, but perfect for a novice who would like to sit in the cockpit and go, practice is the best way to learn :)

DTFSc is a subset of FSX, with some enhancements and changes:

- Sim engine moved to 64 bits. The entry to a new modern platform for building future simulators. The result is visible, I’ve noticed enhanced framerates in all areas (from x1.5 to x2), at ultra-high settings (running an ASUS ROG with i7-6700HQ and GTX 960m). Also, NO crash experienced so far.
- New worldwide terrain, designed with ORBX. I’ve compared it with FSX+ORBX Global+vector+LC EU+LC NA, and Flight School terrain and airports are MUCH better at least in the areas I’ve visited, in UK and USA! That’s for me the major step up of the sim environment in DTFSc, along with better framerates. And for a 15$ product, there’s no comment compared to the price of the ORBX suite only!
- The 2 GA Airplanes are fine, Cub and PA28 are perfect for training and VFR
- DTFSc is VFR only. No IFR, and everything around IFR like ILS, autopilot, has been removed. But no use here in the concept of learning flight basics and flying GA.
- The remaining is mostly some brush up cosmetic changes from FSX, like a new interactive map to plan flights (much interactive and easier to use), new UI, and simplified configuration (in some way a “gaming-like” setting).
- Some points of surprise: Skies and ATC. Skies are very basic like original FSX (could be rendered much better with REX) and ATC voices are unnatural. 2 axes of improvements, hope for the future sim, but DTFSc is not aimed as being the long term sim that will take over FSX on the market.
Finally, a good entertainment product!

And kudos to the devs and teams who have taken over millions of lines of code developed during 25 years by hundreds of others, I know for sure that’s not an easy task to fulfil. Result is promising anyway for the future.
